Message.Title: What shorts are forgetting
Message.Msg: 17 billion in revenue is no joke. If things started to go bad then all Amazon would have to do is shed one of their many initiatives and generate cash. The street recognizes that 17 billion is a BIG DEAL. Shorts that have been trained to look at traditional valuations do not understand. This is not a "flash in the pan" this is a real company (a big company) that is changing the game. At some point in the future the price will become stagnant like all big companies but this will not happen until after profitability has been reached and growth has been slowed. Also, it will not lead to a 100 point drop like many shorts are hoping. It is a gradual metamorphosis (see microsoft, dell and apple).

Topic.Title: What shorts are forgetting

Message.Msg: not that is matters right now, but one might take a counter stance to the long run investment in AMZN based on what you say: yes, $17 billion is not a small deal? but the question is : why has AMZN not been able to get "scale" to the bottom line as they increased sales to $70 billion +? 5 years ago, that was the story analysts were implying as sales increased. Sure ,some is spending initiatives, but many of those are capitalized, blance sheet items: cash to PPE, or cash to equipment) etc, and they still have negative real cash flow. Of course the consumer likes AMZN, they get more out of them then they have to pay for their services, in order for AMZN to show those $17 billion numbers. But's it's still,as an investor, not gonna be able to increase equity, that can used to pay you in the future. It's all in apprecation of the stock on a moving target: which is now qtrs upon qtrs of negative cash flow and earnings, while the stock goes parabolic. So an investor is relying on that condtion continuing. As an investor, you'd like to see them start to build up stockholder equity at some point. For a trader, it's different: they'll chase it until the stock doesn't work going up anymore: two different scenarios.

Message.Title: CSFB Analysis is a complete Joke
Message.Msg: CSFB raises price target 33% (from $330 to $439) while lowering Earnings estimates for CY13, CY14 & CY15 by 51%, 47% and 32% respectively. They model CY15 P/E to 78 to set their price (discounted to 100x in today's $) While they were disappointed that AMZN missed CSOI estimates of $439M by 45% (came in at $267M), they were pumped about revenue and the shipping revenue increase (even though they admitted shipping costs ran well above estimates). They say they like to focus on GM$ (which has to goes up faster than revenue due to AMZN accounting for service revenue at 100% margin, all costs are in opex) - even though Opex $ go up faster than GM$ (hence why CSOI missed estimates). So higher revs lead to more losses, earnings estimates slashed, and raise the price target 33%! Every line of the report got more and more insane as they tried to justify a price increase while reducing every metric they track. What a scam.

Message.Title: Own stock as Compliment
Message.Msg: This is one of the few stocks I own as a compliment, not as an investment. Of course I am not sad that the stock is making increasing in price as well. What does this mean? I have odd reading habits. Most of what I want will not be in the average book store, and it would be a chore to search for the titles in used book stores. Now I can sit back, order what I want used, pay almost nothing for it (usually), and get it in 7-10 days. The site is also good when I want something odd in the house. I don't know where else I would have found a new head for my electric shaver when the old own wore out. Or stop-leak power steering fluid that wasn't in my local auto-supply store. I have no idea why can't make a profit putting books in boxes and selling them. My guess they are trying too hard to be big rather than profitable. I also think they should fry in hell for "patenting" the one-click sing-on, and the American justice system should at least to go purgatory for giving their claim some credibility. As for the pricing, I think our society has too much money and not enough real investment opportunities. I am glad the money is chasing stocks, of which I own some, rather than making things I buy more expensive. But this may change.

Message.Title: Next Stock to Explode Upward
Message.Msg: Agria (GRO) looks ready to explode upward from its current price of $1.47. GRO's 80.81% owned Agria Asia subsidiary owns a controlling 50.22% stake in PGG Wrightson (PGW.NZ), the largest agriculture company in New Zealand. PGG Wrightson is projecting EBITDA this fiscal year of NZ$52-$56mm (USD$44-$47mm), which will equal huge growth of 14%-22%. Agria Asia's 50.22% of PGG Wrightson's projected EBITDA is USD$22.1-$23.6mm. GRO's 80.81% of Agria Asia's projected EBITDA is USD$17.85-$19.07mm. GRO also owns a China seeds business which will likely add about USD$2 million to GRO's EBITDA, which could give GRO total EBITDA of $19.85-$21.07mm. A valuation of just 10X EBITDA could give GRO a market cap of $198.5mm-$210.7mm. With 55.38mm shares outstanding, this would equal a GRO share price of $3.58-$3.80. GRO just reduced its debt to $75mm, with short-term debt of $43mm and $32mm that matures in May 2008. GRO has $26.8mm in pledged restricted cash deposits that can be used towards paying off its debt plus another $42.7 million in unrestricted cash. Therefore, GRO's net debt is only $5.5mm and GRO will likely receive over $10mm in cash dividend payments from PGW.NZ next year. Disclaimer: We own 550,000 shares of GRO and intend to sell these shares at much higher prices.

Message.Title: WMT never lost money!
Message.Msg: As a consumer, I adore AMZN. Though I can't figure out how they can ever make money, when they two day UPS ship a bottle of shampoo for $1.00! As an investor, I'm baffled. Great growth stocks (like WMT) didn't have any losing quarters when they went up 10000%, especially retailers. If a retailer loses money, it's common shares will get hammered. Tech stocks like GOOG and MSFT have, to the best of my knowledge, NEVER had a losing quarter while public. AMZN doesn't break down it's sales and profits, so we really don't know what is going on - it's a black box. Assuming that most of their "profits" get plowed back into the company for new warehouses, technology, businesses - when will that ever end? Or even slowdown? With all the other retailers online, AMZN doesn't really have any pricing power. Not sure how any wall street analyst (whom I have little to no respect for) can make estimates and price targets for this stock, when they don't know the details. I'm not a frustrated investor (there are many other stocks I've owned and sold that are up MUCH more than AMZN the last year, on a percentage basis), but rather an RIA...I have clients who ask me about this stock or own it and want advice. This isn't 1999, when EVERY tech stock was soaring. This is one of the top 20 stocks by markep cap in the USA, yet the only one that is not profitable in the top 200? What would you tell you clients?

Message.Msg: I'm going to start up a company that sells dollar bills for 91 cents. Hopefully, I can sell around 17 billion of my dollar bills this coming qtr. so that I can go public and get my company valued at $160B. What a joke these WS analysts are!! Do they not understand that as soon as you start selling the dollar bill at more than a dollar, your revenue declines rapidly? People use Amazon because they sell things at a loss (after all costs are considered). As soon as they focus on making profits, their top line revenue will suffer. Consumers aren't idiots. They will quickly figure out that WMT, TGT, BBY, etc. are just as competitive on pricing when AMZN raises their item and/or shipping prices. Additionally, neighborhood brick and mortar stores have a better (and cheaper) mechanism to return items. Who wants to spend $20 to return a $50 item when they could just stop by a store on the way home from work. Again, these WS analysts are book smart, but lack common sense imo.

Message.Title: A good quote to remember
Message.Msg: Hussmann wrote it in his weekly column: From my standpoint, the more apt perspective is that of J. Paul Getty (whom I also quoted in 2000, and at the May highs, a few percent from current levels). Getty wrote: “For as long as I can remember, veteran businessmen and investors – I among them – have been warning about the dangers of irrational stock speculation and hammering away at the theme that stock certificates are deeds of ownership and not betting slips… The professional investor has no choice but to sit by quietly while the mob has its day, until the enthusiasm or panic of the speculators and non-professionals has been spent. He is not impatient, nor is he even in a very great hurry, for he is an investor, not a gambler or a speculator. The seeds of any bust are inherent in any boom that outstrips the pace of whatever solid factors gave it its impetus in the first place. There are no safeguards that can protect the emotional investor from himself.”

Message.Title: Good article by robert weinstein
Message.Msg: "The investment thesis follows along a path that assumes once Amazon finally reaches some magical pie-in-the-sky size, they will simply increase prices and shareholders will be rewarded with incredible margins that on other retailer- online or off, can match. Where I come from that's called a bubble. Bubbles can last a long time as the housing market demonstrated for years. The weak link for Amazon shareholders is how unlikely the company can achieve pricing power over and above other dominant retailers. Adding physical locations won't work, Wal-Mart has more locations than anyone. Selling digital media is a margin race to the bottom. Cloud hosting is a low-margin business with low barriers to entry that already includes Microsoft(MSFT_), Google(GOOG_), Rackspace(RAX_), IBM(IBM_) and countless others. Good luck trying to achieve outsized margins in that space. If it's so obvious that at some point the music will stop -- without enough chairs for everyone, why do investors continue to hold and buy more shares? Because what makes a bubble a bubble is investors ignore everything negative and focus on anything that supports the bull case. It literally becomes an investment supposedly worth buying simply because the price continues to climb. Why did tulips trade for more than a year's pay, Molycorp(MCP_) (another company I warned about) or Crocs(CROX_) for over $70? For the same reason a company can trade for $350 that may not generate a profit next year, the mob doesn't care why it's appreciating, until it's not. Hopefully, you care enough not to get caught up in the euphoria and avoid the Amazon musical chair game, or at least be quick enough to grab a chair when the music stops. "

Topic.Title: Bezos to discuss new business initiatives on the cmoing CC

Message.Msg: From a business point of view, Amazon the company is in a dangerous Zone. 1. A lot of the so-called revenue "growth" in Europe comes from favorable currency conversion rate, as dollar reached a 8-month low , not organic growth, on top of selling stuff at or below cost; this will not sustain. 2. Now it has spread itself too thin, trying to cover different businesses, but none of which is Amazon's proprietary territory. The history is that when a business try to do everything (but none of which is its proprietary property), it will end up gradually losing its edge in all fronts. With now Amazon having built Warehouses everywhere, there is no difference between Amazon and Walmart, etc any more. In fact, those Brick-and-Mortar companies actually have more advantages by having those physical stores already be in presence. 3. in the 1990s to early 2000s, Microsoft tried to take the "world", acted aggressively to weed out other competing companies, exactly the same way as Amazon has been doing for sometimes now. Then what happened? The Government stepped in, took on the company(Microsoft) with Anti-trust suits and killed it from there, for fear that type of suppressing competition behavior would hurt consumers' best interest. Amazon's aggressive behavior toward competition simply can not continue. 4. With Twitter, Alibaba IPOs coming soon, far more greener pasture elsewhere with far far less risk., hence, I say "sell" your investment positions now before others taking the action (but never short it). By the way, today the fund managers pushed and held this up for Window dressing, as expected.
